title: Busan’s Shipping Mega-Complex Nears Completion
text:
Terminal Operating Systems Busan’s Shipping Mega-Complex Nears Completion South Korea’s booming port city Busan has completed its maritime cluster as part of its Dongsam-dong Innovation District, with the Busan Port Authority (BPA) announcing that its Busan Vessel Traffic System has moved into the complex. 
The overall project is anticipated to be completed in 2017, according to IHS Maritime 360 . 
President of the BPA, and soon to be Secretary-General of the International Maritime Organization , Kim Li-Tack recently wrote a Technical Paper for PTI in which he outlined Busan Port’s ambitious goal of achieving a 20 million TEU throughput in 2015. 
Read Kim Li-Tack’s paper here 
BPA recently announced that it handled just over 1.6 million TEU in July, making it a total of 11.3 million TEU handled from January to July, 2015. These figures mean that Busan has to improve on a 1.6 million throughput per month if it’s to reach its ambitious 20 million TEU goal for 2015. 
However, with peaks witnessed in winter months as demand increases, Busan could quite viably hit a higher monthly average of around 1.8 TEU handled to creep over the 20 million TEU mark yet. 
The Dongsam-dong Innovation District has been constructed to be a research and education hub for the maritime industry, and built near the port to ensure smooth discourse between both entities. 
It is another ambitious modernising project at the port, with Busan already constructing its ‘distripark’ that aims to optimise assembly and packaging operations, its North Port with a focus on tourism, and it’s the creation of Busan New Port which aims to be the logistics hub for Northeast Asia. 
It was also recently reported that Busan aims to become the world’s number two port by focussing on being Asia’s key transhipment hub. 
When Kim Li-Tack departs as President of the BPA, it has been announced that Woo Ye-jong will be his successor .
